elements.content: Luminescent metal–organic frameworks (LMOFs) are promising functional materials for sustainable applications, where an analyte-induced multiresponsive system with good recyclability is beneficial for detecting numerous lethal pollutants. We designed and built the dual-functionalized, three-dimensional Zn­(II)–framework [Zn3(bpg)1.5(azdc)3]·(DMF)5.9·(H2O)1.05 (CSMCRI-1) using an −OH group-integrated bpg linker and a −NN– moiety containing H2 azdc ligand, which functions as a unique tetrasensoric fluorescent probe. The activated CSMCRI-1 (1′) represents the hitherto unreported pillar-layer framework for extremely selective fluorescence quenching by nitrofurazone antibiotics as well as explosive nitro-aromatic 2,4,6-trinitrophenol, where ultrasensitive detection is achieved for both the electron-lacking analytes. Impressively, 1′ represents the first ever MOF for significant fluorescence “turn-on” detection of toxic and electron-rich 4-aminophenol in the concurrent presence of isomeric analogues. Density functional theory calculations highlight the specific importance of pillar functionalization in the “turn-on” or “turn-off” responses of 1′ by electronically divergent toxic organics and provide further proof of supramolecular interactions between the framework and analytes. The fluorescence intensity of 1′ dramatically quenches by a trace amount of Fe3+ ions over other competing metal ions, alongside visible colorimetric change of the framework in solid and solution phase upon Fe3+ encapsulation. The sensing ability of 1′ remains unaltered for multiple cycles toward all lethal pollutants. The sensing mechanism is attributed to both dynamic and static quenching as well as resonance energy transfer, which strongly comply with the predictions of theoretical simulations. Considering the long-term and real-time monitoring, AND as well as OR molecular logic gates are constructed based on the discriminative fluorescence response for each analyte that provides a platform to fabricate smart LMOFs with multimode logic operations.

elements.content: With excessive economic growth caused by urbanization, an increasing number of chemicals are produced to meet the ever-increasing demand for various industrial products. This leads to severe environmental contamination, where various organic as well as inorganic pollutants pose serious threats to human health and environment. For example, antibiotics, though emerged as an important class of pharmaceuticals to cure bacterial infections, their extreme toxicity, degradation difficulty, and continuous release without thorough eradication conferred them as serious organic pollutants. Particularly, nitro-containing antibiotics nitrofurazone (NZF), which increases resistance to bacterial infections in aquaculture, is in the “list of drugs prohibited in animal foods” because NZF-contaminated foods cause hereditary genetic defects, immunity decline, and cancer. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop a fast, selective, and sensitive detection technique for this antibiotic. On the other hand, nitro-aromatic compounds (NACs) are a class of utmost toxic and hazardous chemicals and can never be neglected. The most frequently applied NAC is 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) that is enormously released in the environment, causing serious health problems such as anemia, respiratory organ injury, and gene mutation. Also, TNP has stronger explosive power than other common nitro compounds. Accordingly, it is of enduring importance to detect the minute presence of TNP with regard to homeland security, military applications, and forensic science. Besides, the recent need is to establish a reliable and sensitive chemical sensor for the recognition of phenolic compounds for controlling food quality, environmental safety, and health and protection, as they are classified as “priority pollutants” by both the European Commission and the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Among others, 4-aminophenol (4-AP) is highly carcinogenic and poses serious threat toward health and environment.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

With excessive economic growth caused by urbanization, an increasing number of chemicals are produced to meet the ever-increasing demand for various industrial products. This leads to severe environmental contamination, where various organic as well as inorganic pollutants pose serious threats to human health and environment. For example, antibiotics, though emerged as an important class of pharmaceuticals to cure bacterial infections, their extreme toxicity, degradation difficulty, and continuous release without thorough eradication conferred them as serious organic pollutants. Particularly, nitro-containing antibiotics nitrofurazone (NZF), which increases resistance to bacterial infections in aquaculture, is in the "list of drugs prohibited in animal foods" because NZF-contaminated foods cause hereditary genetic defects, immunity decline, and cancer. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop a fast, selective, and sensitive detection technique for this antibiotic. On the other hand, nitro-aromatic compounds (NACs) are a class of utmost toxic and hazardous chemicals and can never be neglected. The most frequently applied NAC is 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) that is enormously released in the environment, causing serious health problems such as anemia, respiratory organ injury, and gene mutation. Also, TNP has stronger explosive power than other common nitro compounds. Accordingly, it is of enduring importance to detect the minute presence of TNP with regard to homeland security, military applications, and forensic science. Besides, the recent need is to establish a reliable and sensitive chemical sensor for the recognition of phenolic compounds for controlling food quality, environmental safety, and health and protection, as they are classified as "priority pollutants" by both the European Commission and the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Among others, 4-aminophenol (4-AP) is highly carcinogenic and poses serious threat toward health and environment.

elements.content: Likewise, iron has experienced an ever-growing attention in environmental and biological systems, owing to its consequence and function in the oxygen uptake and metabolic processes. Although Fe3+ ions in moderate concentration is desirable in living systems, this metal ion is now considered as an industrial pollutant, and its overloading or deficiency causes numerous biological complications such as endotoxemia or hepatic cirrhosis. Because luminescent-based detection provides a simplistic method with high selectivity, sensitivity, and accuracy, construction of fluorescent-based sensors has prompted the development of methods for the monitoring of Fe3+ ions in solution. However, shaping an effective Fe3+ ion sensor is still limited by (i) its cross-sensitivity toward other metal ions, (ii) its bad absorbing ability, and (iii) the meticulous synthesis of probe materials. Above all, the current commercial methods and technique-based instruments for detecting all of the aforesaid pollutants are time-consuming, expensive, and single analyte directed devices with complicated procedures that necessitate fabricating a highly effective, multifunctional material to be applied easily for a broad range of lethal pollutants.

elements.content: In this milieu, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a flourishing subclass of porous crystalline materials, with potential applications in gas storage, separation, and catalysis. Fluorescence sensing is another captivating area for MOFs, where ultrahigh surface areas, modifiable porosities, wide range of host–guest interactions, and functionalized pore walls are the major benefits. Thanks to the exceptional luminescent features of spectroscopically silent metal ions in juxtaposition with diverse π-conjugated organic ligands that are used to construct efficient fluorescent MOFs. However, major pressing problems concerning the synthesis of luminescent MOFs involve (i) flexible coordination geometry of metal ions, (ii) difficulty in attaching appropriate signal transmission groups to the MOF backbone, and (iii) lack of specific recognition of analytes on the molecular level for effective signal modulation with measurable change. In addition, the energy or electron-transfer mechanism between the host and guest molecules mostly results in a “turn-off” fluorescence response, which urges the development of more favorable “turn-on” responsive MOFs for chemical sensing.
elements.clean_text: In this milieu, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a flourishing subclass of porous crystalline materials, with potential applications in gas storage, separation, and catalysis. Fluorescence sensing is another captivating area for MOFs, where ultrahigh surface areas, modifiable porosities, wide range of host-guest interactions, and functionalized pore walls are the major benefits. Thanks to the exceptional luminescent features of spectroscopically silent metal ions in juxtaposition with diverse π-conjugated organic ligands that are used to construct efficient fluorescent MOFs. However, major pressing problems concerning the synthesis of luminescent MOFs involve (i) flexible coordination geometry of metal ions, (ii) difficulty in attaching appropriate signal transmission groups to the MOF backbone, and (iii) lack of specific recognition of analytes on the molecular level for effective signal modulation with measurable change. In addition, the energy or electron-transfer mechanism between the host and guest molecules mostly results in a "turn-off" fluorescence response, which urges the development of more favorable "turn-on" responsive MOFs for chemical sensing.

elements.content: In view of the above facts and our quest to develop a single, multifunctionalized MOF with a wide range of applications, the present research strategy evolved by selecting the bpg linker, where methylene group bestows flexibility to the target framework, and pendent −OH functionalities should offer additional binding sites to the guest molecules. The unpredictability of the targeted MOF using such a flexible linker is judiciously balanced by employing an azo group-functionalized H2 azdc ligand, where the formation of paddle-wheel secondary-building units (SBUs) strengthens the stability and dictates the porosity of the resulting pillar-layer framework CSMCRI-1 (CSMCRI = Central Salt & Marine Chemicals Research Institute). The activated framework demonstrates extremely selective quenching of NZF and TNP, with a very low limit of detection (LOD). Importantly, the unique fluorescence “turn-on” detection of toxic 4-AP, among the isomeric analogues, is realized. Such “turn-off” or “turn-on” responses are exclusively governed by the individual electronic properties of these aromatics, where density functional theory (DFT) calculations highlight the impact of pillar functionalization and provide proof of diverse supramolecular interactions between the framework and electronically dissimilar toxic organics. The multisensoric behavior of the framework is certified by the exceptionally discriminative fluorescence quenching of Fe3+ ions with a visible color change. The quenching mechanism for all analytes is ascribed to the presence of dynamic plus static quenchings and resonance energy transfer (RET). The importance of selective and sensitive detection of noxious and hazardous compounds is further amplified when the spectral outputs can be transformed to real-time application. In this context, construction of molecular devices using basic building methodology as logic gates and formation of truth tables containing spectral inputs are practically desirable. Along this line, we constructed a molecular logic gate from selective luminescent recognition of NZF, TNP, 4-AP, and Fe3+ ions by the framework. Although discriminative detection of different analytes has been reported based on logic operations, such reports on the construction of MOF-based logic gates are rare. To the best of our knowledge, the dual-functionalized CSMCRI-1 represents the first example of a pillar-layer-based, multiresponsive, ultrasensitive, and recyclable luminescent MOF sensor that can be used for environments with a variety of pollution sources.

elements.content: The block-shaped, orange crystals of CSMCRI-1 were synthesized by the solvothermal reaction of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, H2 azdc, and bpg (1:1:1) in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 90 °C in 48 h. In spite of the poor crystallinity, we were able to collect single-crystal X-ray diffraction data on a selected crystal, which revealed that it crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ (Table S1). The asymmetric unit contains three Zn­(II) ions, three deprotonated azdc ligands, and one and a half bpg linkers (Figure S1). Additionally, we could locate DMF and water molecules as uncoordinated guest solvents. However, these guest molecules are highly disordered that is common in organic–inorganic hybrid porous structures. Close insight into the structure of CSMCRI-1 reveals that the equatorial positions of two Zn­(II) ions are coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, originating from four azdc ligands, to construct paddle-wheel {Zn2(CO2)4} SBUs (a). These SBUs are connected through azdc ligands to form two-dimensional square grids (Figure S1). The axial pillaring to the SBUs by the nitrogen atoms of bpg linkers affords an extended three-dimensional (3D) pillar-layer framework with α-Po topology (Figure S2), which is typical for mixed ligand-based MOFs. In the SBUs, each five-coordinated Zn­(II) ion adopts a square pyramidal geometry with a Zn–N bond length of 2.033(3) Å and average Zn–O bond lengths of 2.018 Å, which are in the normal range. A simplified version of this extended structure is depicted in b that shows the formation of a box-shaped structure. The distances between the diagonal Zn­(II) atoms approximates to 27.50 Å (distances excludes van der Waals radii), generating large pores. Structural analysis with TOPOS reveals a 6-c unimodal net with the corresponding Schläfli symbol {412·63} (Figure S2). Importantly, the uncoordinated −OH groups of bpg linker are directed toward the pore, implementing an electron-rich and hydrophilic environment to the cavity. On the other hand, −NN– moieties in azdc ligands are part of the MOF wall, manifesting the electron-deficient nature of the pore. Such dual functionalization in CSMCRI-1 should be advantageous for sensing applications. The introduction of extended dicarboxylate ligands and long dipyridyl linkers leads to the generation of huge pores that instigates threefold interpenetration to the overall 3D structure (c). As a result, the pore dimension is significantly reduced, where every large pore in the box-shaped structure is divided into differently sized voids. When viewed through the crystallographic a axis, the larger cavity shows a pore size of 8.8 × 8.9 Å2, whereas a smaller sized pore has a dimension of 4.4 × 8.9 Å2 (d). Both these pores are filled with guest solvent molecules. Despite threefold interpenetration, PLATON calculation suggests the presence of large solvent-accessible volumes of 48.0%.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of CSMCRI-1 

The block-shaped, orange crystals of CSMCRI-1 were synthesized by the solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, H2 azdc, and bpg (1:1:1) in N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 90 °C in 48 h. In spite of the poor crystallinity, we were able to collect single-crystal X-ray diffraction data on a selected crystal, which revealed that it crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ (Table S1). The asymmetric unit contains three Zn(II) ions, three deprotonated azdc ligands, and one and a half bpg linkers (Figure S1). Additionally, we could locate DMF and water molecules as uncoordinated guest solvents. However, these guest molecules are highly disordered that is common in organic-inorganic hybrid porous structures. Close insight into the structure of CSMCRI-1 reveals that the equatorial positions of two Zn(II) ions are coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, originating from four azdc ligands, to construct paddle-wheel {Zn2(CO2)4} SBUs (a). These SBUs are connected through azdc ligands to form two-dimensional square grids (Figure S1). The axial pillaring to the SBUs by the nitrogen atoms of bpg linkers affords an extended three-dimensional (3D) pillar-layer framework with α-Po topology (Figure S2), which is typical for mixed ligand-based MOFs. In the SBUs, each five-coordinated Zn(II) ion adopts a square pyramidal geometry with a Zn-N bond length of 2.033(3) Å and average Zn-O bond lengths of 2.018 Å, which are in the normal range. A simplified version of this extended structure is depicted in b that shows the formation of a box-shaped structure. The distances between the diagonal Zn(II) atoms approximates to 27.50 Å (distances excludes van der Waals radii), generating large pores. Structural analysis with TOPOS reveals a 6-c unimodal net with the corresponding Schläfli symbol {412⋅63} (Figure S2). Importantly, the uncoordinated -OH groups of bpg linker are directed toward the pore, implementing an electron-rich and hydrophilic environment to the cavity. On the other hand, -NN- moieties in azdc ligands are part of the MOF wall, manifesting the electron-deficient nature of the pore. Such dual functionalization in CSMCRI-1 should be advantageous for sensing applications. The introduction of extended dicarboxylate ligands and long dipyridyl linkers leads to the generation of huge pores that instigates threefold interpenetration to the overall 3D structure (c). As a result, the pore dimension is significantly reduced, where every large pore in the box-shaped structure is divided into differently sized voids. When viewed through the crystallographic a axis, the larger cavity shows a pore size of 8.8 × 8.9 Å2, whereas a smaller sized pore has a dimension of 4.4 × 8.9 Å2 (d). Both these pores are filled with guest solvent molecules. Despite threefold interpenetration, PLATON calculation suggests the presence of large solvent-accessible volumes of 48.0%.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of CSMCRI-1 under N2 atmosphere shows a two-step weight loss (calcd 25.32 wt %) that corresponds to the release of water and DMF guest molecules (Figure S3a). The desolvated CSMCRI-1 (hereafter 1′) does not reveal any plateau up to 370 °C and decomposes thereafter. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-synthesized crystals reveals complete agreement with that of the simulated pattern, indicating high crystallinity and phase purity of the sample (a). Desolvation leads to a slight shift of Bragg’s reflections (a) that may result because of the release of solvent guests from the porous channel. Interestingly, the low-angle peaks were restored upon exposure of 1′ to DMF (a). It is worth mentioning that such a modification in the PXRD patterns upon desolvation and resolvation is not unique and has been realized in the interpenetrated pillar-layer frameworks. In addition, stability of CSMCRI-1 was checked in diverse organic solvents as well as in water and open air. As displayed in b, the characteristic peaks in PXRD remain unchanged in all cases up to 24 h, whereas slight broadening of peaks occurs upon exposure to water for a prolonged time. Variable temperature PXRD up to 250 °C reveals sufficient stability of the framework (Figure S4). To assess the permanent porosity, nitrogen gas sorption isotherm was attempted. Prior to measurement, the guest solvents in the as-synthesized crystals were exchanged with dichloromethane and degassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate 1′. The framework shows 86 cm3/g of N2 gas uptake at 77 K up to 1.0 relative pressure (P/P 0) that corresponds to a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 112.69 m2/g. The result corroborates the presence of porosity (Figure S3b) and further indicates that the −OH groups of the linker do not appreciably reduce the accessible space in 1′.

Establishment of Stability and Permanent Porosity

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of CSMCRI-1 under N2 atmosphere shows a two-step weight loss (calcd 25.32 wt %) that corresponds to the release of water and DMF guest molecules (Figure S3a). The desolvated CSMCRI-1 (hereafter 1') does not reveal any plateau up to 370 °C and decomposes thereafter. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-synthesized crystals reveals complete agreement with that of the simulated pattern, indicating high crystallinity and phase purity of the sample (a). Desolvation leads to a slight shift of Bragg's reflections (a) that may result because of the release of solvent guests from the porous channel. Interestingly, the low-angle peaks were restored upon exposure of 1' to DMF (a). It is worth mentioning that such a modification in the PXRD patterns upon desolvation and resolvation is not unique and has been realized in the interpenetrated pillar-layer frameworks. In addition, stability of CSMCRI-1 was checked in diverse organic solvents as well as in water and open air. As displayed in b, the characteristic peaks in PXRD remain unchanged in all cases up to 24 h, whereas slight broadening of peaks occurs upon exposure to water for a prolonged time. Variable temperature PXRD up to 250 °C reveals sufficient stability of the framework (Figure S4). To assess the permanent porosity, nitrogen gas sorption isotherm was attempted. Prior to measurement, the guest solvents in the as-synthesized crystals were exchanged with dichloromethane and degassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate 1'. The framework shows 86 cm3/g of N2 gas uptake at 77 K up to 1.0 relative pressure (P/P 0) that corresponds to a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 112.69 m2/g. The result corroborates the presence of porosity (Figure S3b) and further indicates that the -OH groups of the linker do not appreciably reduce the accessible space in 1'.

elements.content: The presence of electronically passive d10 transition metal ions together with highly conjugated aromatic ligands allows the dual-functionalized CSMCRI-1 to act as a potential fluorophore with venerable photoluminescence (PL) properties. To find the best-suited solvent for the fluorescence experiment, we dispersed 1′ in a series of solvents (1 mg in 20 mL of solvent), and individual suspensions were excited at the excitation wavelength. The maximum fluorescence emission intensity of 1′ was achieved in DMF (Figure S6c), which insisted us to perform all sensing experiments in this solvent. A homogeneous dispersion of 1′ (1 mg in 2 mL of DMF) exhibits strong fluorescence emission at 388 nm with a shoulder near 427 nm, when excited at 350 nm at room temperature. The significant emission can be attributed to the mixed involvement of the intraligand charge-transfer transition of π-electron-rich ligands (π–π* and n−π* transitions) and ample π–π stacking interaction between the ligands in the interpenetrated structure as well as the photoswitching aptitude (trans → cis) of the azdc ligand. Additionally, the ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectra of 1′ displays red shifts of 17 and 81 nm compared to those of free H2 azdc and bpg, respectively (Figure S6a), which stems from the perturbation effect due to their coordination with Zn­(II) ions. Impressively, the framework exhibits large 88 and 79% intensity enhancements than the free carboxylate ligand and pyridyl linker correspondingly, ascribing a strong electronic communication between the neighboring coordinated ligands through Zn­(II) ions (Figure S6b). Such ligand-centered emission is highly anticipated as their modification in the band gaps because of host–guest interactions may lead to different fluorescent responses, including changes in the luminescence intensity and position. Hence, the luminescent performance of this MOF was investigated in detail toward diverse lethal pollutants.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Studies

The presence of electronically passive d10 transition metal ions together with highly conjugated aromatic ligands allows the dual-functionalized CSMCRI-1 to act as a potential fluorophore with venerable photoluminescence (PL) properties. To find the best-suited solvent for the fluorescence experiment, we dispersed 1' in a series of solvents (1 mg in 20 mL of solvent), and individual suspensions were excited at the excitation wavelength. The maximum fluorescence emission intensity of 1' was achieved in DMF (Figure S6c), which insisted us to perform all sensing experiments in this solvent. A homogeneous dispersion of 1' (1 mg in 2 mL of DMF) exhibits strong fluorescence emission at 388 nm with a shoulder near 427 nm, when excited at 350 nm at room temperature. The significant emission can be attributed to the mixed involvement of the intraligand charge-transfer transition of π-electron-rich ligands (π-π* and n-π* transitions) and ample π-π stacking interaction between the ligands in the interpenetrated structure as well as the photoswitching aptitude (trans → cis) of the azdc ligand. Additionally, the ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectra of 1' displays red shifts of 17 and 81 nm compared to those of free H2 azdc and bpg, respectively (Figure S6a), which stems from the perturbation effect due to their coordination with Zn(II) ions. Impressively, the framework exhibits large 88 and 79% intensity enhancements than the free carboxylate ligand and pyridyl linker correspondingly, ascribing a strong electronic communication between the neighboring coordinated ligands through Zn(II) ions (Figure S6b). Such ligand-centered emission is highly anticipated as their modification in the band gaps because of host-guest interactions may lead to different fluorescent responses, including changes in the luminescence intensity and position. Hence, the luminescent performance of this MOF was investigated in detail toward diverse lethal pollutants.

elements.content: As already discussed, antibiotics are essential natural poisons, which urge their discriminative detection. Considering the high porosity, excellent luminescence, and good stability in solution phase, 1′ was initially chosen for the liquid-phase fluorescence sensing of diverse classes of detrimental antibiotics such as nitrofuran (NZF; nitrofurantoin, NFT; furazolidone, FZD), nitroimidazole (metronidazole, MDZ; dimetridazole, DTZ; ornidazole, ODZ), sulfonamides (sulfadiazine, SDZ; sulfamethazine, SMZ), and chloramphenicols (thiamphenicol, THI). Fluorescence titrations were performed by the incremental addition (20–160 μL) of 1 mM stock solution of each antibiotic into the suspension of 1′ (1 mg in 2 mL DMF) at room temperature. The consistency of individual results was cross-checked by performing each titration in triplicate fashion. Successive quenching in the fluorescence intensity of the MOF was observed depending on the presence of specific organic groups and relative sizes in different classes of antibiotics (Figures S8–S15″). Surprisingly, NZF shows a remarkable 91% quenching efficiency upon only 160 μL addition to 1′ (a), whereas NFT and FZD follow sequential quenching efficiency of 87.4 and 83.0% (Figure S7), respectively. Notably, the remaining antibiotics, which do not contain the furan moiety as a part of their molecular structure, showed trivial influence on the emission intensity of 1′ and furnished low quenching efficiencies (b). The quenching competences of the framework for the entire class of antibiotics were found in the order NZF > NFT > FZD ≫ MDZ > DTZ > ODZ > SMZ > SDZ > THI (c and S7). Given that the nitro-containing antibiotics, specifically NZF, are prohibited to exist in food production, such a high level of detection of NZF is positively motivating.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Detection of NZF Antibiotic

As already discussed, antibiotics are essential natural poisons, which urge their discriminative detection. Considering the high porosity, excellent luminescence, and good stability in solution phase, 1' was initially chosen for the liquid-phase fluorescence sensing of diverse classes of detrimental antibiotics such as nitrofuran (NZF; nitrofurantoin, NFT; furazolidone, FZD), nitroimidazole (metronidazole, MDZ; dimetridazole, DTZ; ornidazole, ODZ), sulfonamides (sulfadiazine, SDZ; sulfamethazine, SMZ), and chloramphenicols (thiamphenicol, THI). Fluorescence titrations were performed by the incremental addition (20-160 μL) of 1 mM stock solution of each antibiotic into the suspension of 1' (1 mg in 2 mL DMF) at room temperature. The consistency of individual results was cross-checked by performing each titration in triplicate fashion. Successive quenching in the fluorescence intensity of the MOF was observed depending on the presence of specific organic groups and relative sizes in different classes of antibiotics (Figures S8-S15"). Surprisingly, NZF shows a remarkable 91% quenching efficiency upon only 160 μL addition to 1' (a), whereas NFT and FZD follow sequential quenching efficiency of 87.4 and 83.0% (Figure S7), respectively. Notably, the remaining antibiotics, which do not contain the furan moiety as a part of their molecular structure, showed trivial influence on the emission intensity of 1' and furnished low quenching efficiencies (b). The quenching competences of the framework for the entire class of antibiotics were found in the order NZF > NFT > FZD ≫ MDZ > DTZ > ODZ > SMZ > SDZ > THI (c and S7). Given that the nitro-containing antibiotics, specifically NZF, are prohibited to exist in food production, such a high level of detection of NZF is positively motivating.

elements.content: To explore more on such efficient sensing of NZF and quantitatively assess the quenching phenomena, concentration-dependent decrease in the fluorescence intensity of 1′ was plotted by using Stern–Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I) = K SV[A] + 1, where K SV is the quenching constant (M–1), [A] is the molar concentration of the analyte, and I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after addition of the analyte, respectively. As depicted in Figures S16–S18, the SV plots for nitrofurans are nearly linear in the concentration range of 0–0.05 mM but bend upward as the concentration rises. Such nonlinear SV plots might be a consequence of dynamic and static quenching processes and/or a RET mechanism. Quite in contrast, other classes of antibiotics revealed linear SV plots (c) throughout the whole concentration range (0–0.08 mM). From the linear fitting of the plot, the quenching constants for NZF, NFT, and FZD were calculated to be 8.75 × 104, 5.92 × 104, and 4.8 × 104 M–1, respectively (Figures S19–S21). To the best of our insight, the present quenching constant value for NZF is one of the highest among the reported MOFs for antibiotic sensing (Table S9). Further, the LOD was obtained from the plot of decrease in fluorescence intensity of 1′ upon incremental addition (20–160 μL) of 10 μM NZF solution (Figure S22). The LOD for NZF (Table S2) was found to be 0.8 ppm (0.66 μM) using equation 3σ/K, where σ denotes the standard deviations for five consecutive fluorescent measurements of blank MOF solution at fixed time intervals (2 min), and K signifies the slope of the aforesaid curve. Clearly, the LOD value is comparable or higher than the handful examples of antibiotic sensory MOFs (Table S9), where 1′ stands as a first pillar-layer MOF for the detection of nitrofuran-based NZF antibiotic, as far as we know.

elements.content: Because anti-interference is one of the most important prerequisites for chemical sensors, we performed competitive analytes test of 1′ toward NZF in the presence of potentially interfering other classes of antibiotics, maintaining standard protocol (vide supra). As can be seen from d, a slight or negligible fluorescence change occurs upon addition of 160 μL of interfering analytes (1 mM). In contrast, simultaneous addition of 160 μL of NZF (1 mM) shows rapid and significant quenching of the emission intensity. The results reveal that noteworthy NZF selectivity of the framework is retained even in the presence of a higher concentration of other antibiotics, and interference from rest of the antibiotics can be solemnly neglected (Figures S23–S28). Such exceptionally specific and ultrasensitive detection of NZF in the presence of other analytes confers 1′ as a reliable sensor for NZF. Besides, recyclability as well as reusability of the framework were tested for long-term and real-time monitoring. To this end, the sample was recovered via centrifugation after sensing studies and washed with DMF several times. The regenerated material was used again, and it maintains quenching efficiency up to five sensing-recovery cycles with negligible variation in emission intensities (Figure S29). It should also be pointed that the structure remains intact, as confirmed by the unaltered PXRD patterns of the framework after the sensing experiments (Figure S30).

elements.content: Inspired by the exciting PL behavior and remarkable quenching of the electron-lacking antibiotic NZF, we further explored the potential of 1′ as a sensor for the detection of various hazardous NACs such as TNP, 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), nitrophenols (4-NP, 3-NP, 2-NP), nitrotoluene (4-NT), and aliphatic nitro compound 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-dinitrobutane (DMDNB), which are also electron-deficient in nature. Following the typical procedure (vide supra), changes in the luminescence spectra were monitored by the incremental addition of selected nitro analytes (1 mM in DMF) up to 200 μL to a dispersion of 1 mg of guest-free crystals of CSMCRI-1 (Figures S32–S37). As shown in a, the fluorescence intensity of 1′ radically decreased with the incremental addition of TNP solution. To our delight, 1′ showed a quenching efficiency of 94 and 86% toward TNP and 2,4-DNP, respectively. However, other NACs as well as nitro-aliphatic DMDNB show a minor quenching effect (b,c). The quenching efficiencies were in the order TNP > 2,4-DNP ≫ 4-NP > 3-NP > 2-NP > 4-NT > 2,4-DNT > DMDNB (Figure S31), which firmly validate the selective recognition of TNP. To quantify the quenching constant (K SV) and identify the nature of quenching process (static vs dynamic), S–V plots were obtained by plotting the relative fluorescence intensity [(I 0/I)] with [A] molar concentration of TNP. The curve deviated from linearity at higher concentration (Figure S38), indicating the presence of dynamic and static quenching processes. However, the S–V plots for all other NACs remain linear in nature. The quenching constant for TNP, calculated from the linear region of the above-mentioned curve at lower concentration range (0.0–0.04 mM), was found to be 4.6 × 104 M–1 (Figure S39), which ranks among the highest values to most of the TNP sensory MOFs and comparable to the famous MOFs for TNP detection (Table S10). Essentially, such an extraordinary quenching value further necessitates quantification of LOD, which was calculated by monitoring the quenching effect via incremental addition of 10 μM TNP solution to the dispersion of activated CSMCRI-1 (Figure S42). The LOD was found (Table S4) to be 0.53 ppm (0.4 μM), which is superior to most of the reported MOFs till date (Table S10). Encouraged by its extreme luminescence quenching and coupled with the utmost importance for selective detection of superiorly explosive TNP in the presence of other nitro congeners, we next examined the competitive analytes test of 1′ toward TNP. As shown in d, the pristine emission intensity of the MOF was merely affected by other nitro compounds. On the contrary, simultaneous addition of 200 μL of TNP solution leads to substantial fluorescence quenching (Figures S43–S48). The result clearly manifests the framework as an efficient material for selective and sensitive detection of TNP in the simultaneous presence of other nitro congeners. The reproducibility of emission intensity of the framework has been checked up to five sensing-recovery cycles, which showed that the initial fluorescence intensity of 1′ was virtually restored (vide supra) (Figure S49). Besides, PXRD patterns (Figure S50) of the framework notify no alteration of peaks even after five repetitive cycles of fluorescence titration with 1 mM TNP solution, attesting to the exceptional reusability of the material for long-term, in-field detection of noxious TNP.

elements.content: In general, electron-deficient NACs withdraw electrons from the electron-rich MOF by a host–guest interaction that eventually results in the “turn-off” mode through a decrease in the emission intensity. Motivated by this basic knowledge, we anticipated that electron-rich guests should, in principle, result in a more favorable “turn-on” response in the activated CSMCRI-1. Accordingly, we investigated the fluorescence titration by the successive addition (20–400 μL) of 1 mM stock solution of diverse aminophenolic compounds into the dispersion of 1′ (vide supra) at room temperature. Opposed to nitro explosives or nitrofuran-based antibiotics, the fluorescence response of 1′ enhanced upon addition of aminophenol compounds (a, S51, and S52). In particular, 4-AP results in the most significant “turn-on” response, which is more than 3-fold of the pristine emission intensity of the framework. Although, 3-dimethyl aminophenol and 3-diethyl aminophenol moderately enhance the fluorescence intensity, a negligible “turn-on” response of the framework was witnessed for 3-aminophenol (3-AP) and 2-aminophenol (2-AP) (b,c). This observation clearly manifests high selectivity of the activated CSMCRI-1 toward 4-AP over other isomeric analogues. To further verify this conclusion and analyze the discriminative identification of 4-AP in detail, we performed competitive fluorescence titration experiments (vide supra). The results are depicted in d that divulge negligible effect on emission intensity of the framework upon 400 μL addition of either 2-AP or 3-AP. However, rapid enhancement of fluorescence emission was marked in the synchronous presence of 4-AP. The combined results conclude that 1′ is an outstanding material for selective identification of 4-AP, even when other isomeric aminophenols coexist in the solution. The enhancement constant was obtained using the equation (I/I 0) = K EC[A] + 1, where K EC stands for the enhancement constant (M–1) and other terms bear their own significances (vide supra). K EC was calculated to be 9.34 × 103, 5.14 × 103, and 2.6 × 103 M–1 for 4-AP, 3-dimethyl aminophenol, and 3-diethyl aminophenol, respectively (Figures S53–S55). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of selective luminescent sensing for 4-AP among isomeric aminophenols by any MOF material. We calculated the LOD of 1′ (Figure S56) from fluorescence enhancement via incremental addition of 4-AP (10 μM) to the well-dispersed solution of 1′ (Table S6), which turned out to be 0.17 ppm (0.13 μM). Additionally, the PXRD pattern of the recovered framework (by centrifugation, followed by washing with fresh DMF) exhibits well-matched diffraction peaks to that of CSMCRI-1, corroborating that crystallinity and framework integrity are well-maintained during sensing experiments (Figure S59).

elements.content: The quenching mechanism was investigated in detail to better understand such efficient luminescent sensing of the MOF through either “turn-on” or “turn-off” responses by three different classes of toxic organic aromatics. Beforehand, the encapsulation possibilities for any of the analytes into the framework channel can be ruled out based on the small aperture dimensions of pores in CSMCRI-1. Hence, the interaction of 1′ with antibiotics, nitro explosives, and aminophenols can only be associated with surface adsorption. The miraculous fluorescence quenching of NZF and TNP with pronounced nonlinear S–V plots suggests the concurrent existence of static as well as dynamic quenching events. Given the electron-withdrawing nitro group is present in both these analytes, we provisionally justify the quenching response by a photoinduced electron transfer (PET) mechanism. Though MOFs entail extended network structures, they are envisaged as giant “molecules” because of highly localized electronic structures and involve definite energy gap between the valence band and conduction band (CB). Usually, the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of electron-lacking analytes are located at a lower energy level than the CB of MOF. Upon excitation, quenching occurs by a typical electron transfer from the CB of MOF to the LUMOs of analytes. Accordingly, better quenching is anticipated if the LUMO energy of a particular electron-deficient compound is lower. However, the case is entirely opposite in the case of electron-rich aminophenol, which develops “turn on” mechanism in the framework. In this milieu, the electronic aspects of all studied analytes as well as the −OH functionalized linker were studied in detail. The DFT calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 D.01 package. B3LYP functional and Pople diffuse basis set 6-311++G** have been used for all calculations. In all calculations, we have included Grimme’s dispersion (DFT-D3) corrections to account the effect of weak interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism for Sensing of NZF, TNP, and 4-AP

The quenching mechanism was investigated in detail to better understand such efficient luminescent sensing of the MOF through either "turn-on" or "turn-off" responses by three different classes of toxic organic aromatics. Beforehand, the encapsulation possibilities for any of the analytes into the framework channel can be ruled out based on the small aperture dimensions of pores in CSMCRI-1. Hence, the interaction of 1' with antibiotics, nitro explosives, and aminophenols can only be associated with surface adsorption. The miraculous fluorescence quenching of NZF and TNP with pronounced nonlinear S-V plots suggests the concurrent existence of static as well as dynamic quenching events. Given the electron-withdrawing nitro group is present in both these analytes, we provisionally justify the quenching response by a photoinduced electron transfer (PET) mechanism. Though MOFs entail extended network structures, they are envisaged as giant "molecules" because of highly localized electronic structures and involve definite energy gap between the valence band and conduction band (CB). Usually, the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of electron-lacking analytes are located at a lower energy level than the CB of MOF. Upon excitation, quenching occurs by a typical electron transfer from the CB of MOF to the LUMOs of analytes. Accordingly, better quenching is anticipated if the LUMO energy of a particular electron-deficient compound is lower. However, the case is entirely opposite in the case of electron-rich aminophenol, which develops "turn on" mechanism in the framework. In this milieu, the electronic aspects of all studied analytes as well as the -OH functionalized linker were studied in detail. The DFT calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 D.01 package. B3LYP functional and Pople diffuse basis set 6-311++G** have been used for all calculations. In all calculations, we have included Grimme's dispersion (DFT-D3) corrections to account the effect of weak interactions.

elements.content: The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and LUMO orbital energy plots of the linker in the pristine MOF along with studied electron-deficient and electron rich analytes are depicted in Tables S3, S5, and S7. Compared to the rest of the electron-deficient analytes, the LUMOs of NZF (−3.14 eV) and TNP (−4.30 eV) lie in favorable energy levels that facilitate easy electron transfer from 1′ during fluorescence quenching. In contrast, the LUMO of 4-AP (−0.51 eV) is located at a higher energy level for effective donation of electron to the CB of the framework, leading to fluorescence enhancement effect (a,b and a). For NZF and TNP, an obvious energy redistribution of the LUMO–HOMO orbitals of the MOF constituent along with a substantial reduction in the energy gap (5.74 eV → 3.28 eV for NZF; 5.74 eV → 3.66 eV for TNP) was observed upon such an interaction. As a result, the LUMO energy was stabilized and localized on individual electron-deficient analytes for a favorable electron transfer from an excited state of the probe to the LUMOs of NZF and/or TNP, causing the highest fluorescence quenching. A similar rearrangement of the LUMO–HOMO orbitals and lowering of the energy gap for linker (5.74 eV → 4.60 eV) is also evidenced when electron-rich 4-AP interacts with the MOF constituent, validating easy electron transfer from the CB of 4-AP to the LUMO of 1′ that in turn grounds the “turn-on” response. In addition, the geometry optimizations of bpg with NZF, TNP, and 4-AP molecules were carried out separately, and individual optimized structures revealed diverse supramolecular interactions between the pendent −OH functionality of the linker in CSMCRI-1 and electronically dissimilar toxic organo-aromatics (b–d). Clearly, the fluorescence “turn-on” or “turn-off” responses of the framework are exclusively governed by the individual electronic properties of analytes. The estimated binding energy values for the interaction of NZF, TNP, and 4-AP with the linker molecule are found to be 102.13, 73.85, and 59.50 kJ mol–1, respectively.

elements.content: However, the observed quenching efficiency order is not in perfect accordance with the LUMO energy trend of other analytes. This indicates that RET might be another reason for PL quenching. Essentially, RET depends on the extent of overlap between the emission band of the fluorophore and the absorption band of the nonemissive analyte. As shown in c, the UV–vis absorption spectra of NZF has the largest degree of overlapping with the 388 nm peak in the emission spectra of 1′, followed by NFT, FZD, ODZ, DTZ, MDZ, SAM, CAP, SDZ, and THI. Nevertheless, the peak at 470 nm has no overlap with the absorption spectrum of any of the antibiotics (c). In the case of nitro congeners, TNP (∼444 nm) has a major spectral overlap with the 388 nm peak of 1′, whereas rest of the NACs show a minor overlap in the order 2-NP (∼444 nm) > 4-NP (∼432 nm) > 3-NP (∼340 nm) > 4-NT (∼290 nm) > 2,4-DNT (∼280 nm) > DMDNB (∼270 nm) (d). This in turn signifies that synchronous existence of electron transfer and energy transfer, with a prevalence of the latter mechanism, reasonably explains maximum PL quenching and the observed nonlinearity in the S–V plots for both NZF and TNP. However, the electron-transfer process is the sole mechanism for rest of the antibiotics as well as remaining NACs. On the other hand, the absorption band of 4-AP, though remains closest to the emission band of 1′ among isomeric aminophenols, trivial overlap does not result in much RET as compared to the observed fluorescence enhancement in these classes of analytes (Figure S101). This observation essentially validates that PET is the only mechanism for the observed fluorescence enhancement in the case of electron-rich aminophenolic compounds.

elements.content: The pendent −OH functional groups in the bpg linker can facilitate both electron transfer and binding to metal ions, leading to luminescent quenching-induced detection of metal ions. Although, −OH functionalized organic chromophore molecules and graphene/graphene oxides are explored for highly efficient Fe3+ ion sensing, such functionalization for sensing of this particular metal ion is rare in MOF materials. These facts encouraged us to explore CSMCRI-1 as a prospective luminescent probe to detect metal ions in a rapid, selective, and sensitive manner. At the onset, the luminescence spectra of desolvated CSMCRI-1 was monitored by incremental addition (10 mM) of several metal ions namely Hg2+, Al3+, Mg2+, Ba2+, La3+, Ce3+, Ca2+, Cd2+, K+, Pd2+, Co2+, Mn2+, and Ni2+ that show negligible impact on the luminescence intensity (titration plots for individual metal ions are provided in Supporting Information, Figures S62–S74). In sharp contrast, the biologically important Fe3+ ions displayed rapid quenching of the luminescence intensity of 1′ (a). The quenching efficiency was calculated (vide supra) to be 86% for Fe3+ ions (Figure S60). However, the quenching efficiencies of other metal ions were either low or almost negligible. The quenching competence follows the order Fe3+ ≫ Cu2+ > La3+ > Ni2+ > Al3+ > Hg2+ > Ce3+ > Co2+ > Pd2+ > Cd2+ > Mn2+ > Ca2+ > K+ > Mg2+ > Ba2+ (c and S60). This interesting behavior motivated us to further investigate the effects of Fe3+ ion concentration on the fluorescence intensity of 1′ in detail. To determine the quenching constant (K SV), DMF solution of Fe3+ (5 mM) was added to the MOF dispersion, and the quenching phenomena was observed (Figure S61). The S–V plot deviates from linearity at higher concentration of Fe3+ ions, suggesting the synchronous presence of static and dynamic quenchings (Figure S75). The K SV value, from the linear region of the S–V plot at lower concentration ranges (0–0.04 mM), was calculated to be 2.54 × 104 M–1 (Figure S76), which is superior or comparable to the former MOF-based fluorescent sensors for Fe3+ ion detection (Table S11). Additionally, the LOD for Fe3+ ions was obtained from the standard calculation method (Table S8) that turned out to be 1.71 ppm (1.29 μM). A comparison of detection limits for fluorescent-based Fe3+ sensory MOFs is listed in Table S11. Clearly, 1′ highlights great potential for sensitive detection of Fe3+ ions and exhibits one of the best performances with regard to detection limit among the formerly reported MOFs. Such efficient sensing could be a mutual consequence of the strong Fe3+–framework interaction as well as proper accessibility of this particular metal ion inside the optimum sized cavity. A deeper insight of the structure of CSMCRI-1 reveals that the pendent oxygen atoms (from −OH groups) in the bpg linker are accurately projected through the pores of the channels, assisting the donation of electron lone pairs to the outer most shell of half-filled  orbital in Fe3+ ions. This in turn reduces the energy-transfer efficiency from the ligands to Zn­(II) centers and decreases the luminescent intensity of the framework. To validate this logic further, 1′ was immersed in a Fe3+ solution to result in a Fe3+ ion-incorporated framework. Remarkably, the pictures of the Fe3+ ion-incorporated framework showed a distinct color change from orange to brown, confirming the Fe3+–MOF interaction (a inset). In addition, the pictures of Fe3+ ion-incorporated 1′ in solid state showed a clear change in color from orange to brown. To put more focus on Fe3+ ion encapsulation-induced color change, we studied the variation in the absorbance of 1′ with increasing Fe3+ ion concentration using solid-state UV–vis spectroscopy. The guest-free CSMCRI-1 (10 mg) was dipped in varying concentrations of Fe3+ ion-containing solution (0, 0.5, 1, 2.5, 5, and 10 mM) for effective absorption, filtered after 24 h, and finally dried to check UV–vis spectra. Compared to pristine 1′, the absorbance embraced a sharp enhancement with increasing Fe3+ ion concentration (Figure S92). The plot of absorbance versus concentration for 1′@Fe3+ is linear at lower concentration (0–2.5 mM). However, it becomes nonlinear at higher concentration, corroborating deviation from Beer–Lambert law (Figures S94 and S95). On the contrary, the solid-state UV–vis spectra of 1′ showed negligible variation in absorbance even in the presence of 10 mM of interfering metal ions (Figure S93). Given the visual changes, apart from high luminescent sensitivity, are crucial standard for an ideal chemosensory material, the present results clearly manifest that 1′ changes color upon specific metal encapsulation and can be considered as a naked eye detector for Fe3+ ions.

elements.content: However, possibilities of the framework metal exchange by incoming Fe3+ metal ions as well as Fe3+-ion-induced structural decomposition cannot be excluded during the quenching event. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis resulted in a ratio of 1:6.07 for Fe3+ and Zn2+ ions (Table S12), respectively, in Fe3+ ion-incorporated 1′ that confirms Zn­(II) ions are not exchanged during the quenching process. Afterward, long-term reusability of the framework was checked. For this, the sample was recovered by centrifugation after sensing study with Fe3+ ions and thoroughly washed with fresh DMF. The recovered material was air-dried and reused for fluorescence performance. Satisfactorily, 1′ retained most of its initial fluorescence emission intensity even after five successive cycles of Fe3+ ion-sensing experiments (Figure S96) that validates high reusability of the framework for repeated use during real-time monitoring. Interestingly, PXRD of the framework was maintained throughout these sensing cycles (Figure S97), which emphasizes high stability of the material.

elements.content: Additionally, discriminating identification of Fe3+ ions from a mixture of potentially interfering ions was monitored by the quenching competence test. The emission intensity of well-dispersed MOF solution was checked by addition of 100 μL of diverse interfering metal salt solution (10 mM) followed by 100 μL of Fe3+ solution (10 mM). As depicted in d and S78–S91, the fluorescence intensity quenched remarkably in the presence of Fe3+ ions only, whereas negligible fall of intensity was observed for other metal ions. These cumulative results truly manifest the present pillar-layer framework as a proficient material for a highly selective, sensitive, and naked eye sensor of Fe3+ ions.

elements.content: Numerous examples of fluorescence signaling-based molecular logic gates have been described after the pioneering work by de Silva and co-workers. On the basis of inputs, discriminative recognition of wide range of analytes has also been reported by various other groups. However, development of a molecular logic gate by using responses of MOFs in the presence of different analytes is still infrequent. Excellent selective detection of a wide range of analytes by CSMCRI-1 motivated us to construct logic gates that are made by a combination of AND as well as OR gates. The spectral inputs used were A and B, where A denotes those analytes that show discriminative sensing behavior of the framework, whereas B signifies other interfering analytes showing no/trivial change in the fluorescence intensity. The presence or absence of the inputs is designated by “1” or “0,” respectively, whereas an altered/unaffected fluorescence signal is used as the notation for the output. For example, inputs (0101) and (0011), given by A and B ports, respectively, are combined by the AND gate methodological operation to produce (0001) as outputs. Together, the outcomes from the AND gate and the aforesaid inputs from A were used as combined inputs for the OR gate to generate an overall output (0101) for the coupled molecular logic gate. This term is designated as Y, which signifies the fluorescence outcome of the assembled circuit. Such a combined output was formulated as A + AB. Desired fluorescence signal was detected by output “1,” whereas a negligible luminescence effect was monitored by “0” (a). Along this line, the truth table for the individual logic gate was constructed based on two binary inputs. As displayed in b, the resultant single output from the AND gate and the simultaneous input given to port A were used as combined binary inputs to obtain the main output of the complete circuit.
elements.clean_text:
Construction of Molecular Logic Gate for Device Application

Numerous examples of fluorescence signaling-based molecular logic gates have been described after the pioneering work by de Silva and co-workers. On the basis of inputs, discriminative recognition of wide range of analytes has also been reported by various other groups. However, development of a molecular logic gate by using responses of MOFs in the presence of different analytes is still infrequent. Excellent selective detection of a wide range of analytes by CSMCRI-1 motivated us to construct logic gates that are made by a combination of AND as well as OR gates. The spectral inputs used were A and B, where A denotes those analytes that show discriminative sensing behavior of the framework, whereas B signifies other interfering analytes showing no/trivial change in the fluorescence intensity. The presence or absence of the inputs is designated by "1" or "0," respectively, whereas an altered/unaffected fluorescence signal is used as the notation for the output. For example, inputs (0101) and (0011), given by A and B ports, respectively, are combined by the AND gate methodological operation to produce (0001) as outputs. Together, the outcomes from the AND gate and the aforesaid inputs from A were used as combined inputs for the OR gate to generate an overall output (0101) for the coupled molecular logic gate. This term is designated as Y, which signifies the fluorescence outcome of the assembled circuit. Such a combined output was formulated as A + AB. Desired fluorescence signal was detected by output "1," whereas a negligible luminescence effect was monitored by "0" (a). Along this line, the truth table for the individual logic gate was constructed based on two binary inputs. As displayed in b, the resultant single output from the AND gate and the simultaneous input given to port A were used as combined binary inputs to obtain the main output of the complete circuit.

elements.content: In conclusion, we designed and built a dual-functionalized, pillar-layer MOF, CSMCRI-1, from the hydroxyl group-integrated bpg linker and the azo-functionalized H2 azdc ligand that shows the presence of microporous channels in spite of threefold interpenetration. The high stability, admirable fluorescent property, and −OH and −NN– functionality decorated porous channels render the activated framework (1′) as a unique pillar-layer MOF for extremely selective quenching of both NZF antibiotic and explosive TNP with ultrasensitive detection. To our delight, 1′ demonstrates hitherto unreported, MOF-based sensing of toxic 4-AP among the isomeric analogues, through a significant fluorescence “turn-on” mechanism. Importantly, the fluorescence response of the framework is tuned depending upon the electronic properties of individual toxic organic aromatics. The importance of hydroxyl functionalization in the bpg linker for such “turn-on” or “turn-off” responses is validated by DFT calculations, which also provide evidences of different supramolecular interactions between the framework and analytes. The multiresponsive behavior of the framework is certified by the exceptional quenching of fluorescence by Fe3+ ions over other potentially interfering metal ions. The detection of Fe3+ ions involve a visible colorimetric change in the solid and solution phase upon Fe3+ ion encapsulation, which is important for practical applications. Comprehensive studies indicated that concurrent presence of dynamic and static quenchings as well as RET are responsible for such efficient sensing in 1′, and the results are in harmony with the predictions from theoretical calculations. Besides, AND as well as OR molecular logic gates are constructed based on the discriminative luminescent recognition of each analyte. To our knowledge, the dual-functionalized CSMCRI-1 represents an exclusive example of a tetrasensoric framework with good recyclability that opens up a platform to fabricate smart luminescent MOFs with multimode logic operations for potential detection of diverse harmful pollutants using a single fluorescent material.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we designed and built a dual-functionalized, pillar-layer MOF, CSMCRI-1, from the hydroxyl group-integrated bpg linker and the azo-functionalized H2 azdc ligand that shows the presence of microporous channels in spite of threefold interpenetration. The high stability, admirable fluorescent property, and -OH and -NN- functionality decorated porous channels render the activated framework (1') as a unique pillar-layer MOF for extremely selective quenching of both NZF antibiotic and explosive TNP with ultrasensitive detection. To our delight, 1' demonstrates hitherto unreported, MOF-based sensing of toxic 4-AP among the isomeric analogues, through a significant fluorescence "turn-on" mechanism. Importantly, the fluorescence response of the framework is tuned depending upon the electronic properties of individual toxic organic aromatics. The importance of hydroxyl functionalization in the bpg linker for such "turn-on" or "turn-off" responses is validated by DFT calculations, which also provide evidences of different supramolecular interactions between the framework and analytes. The multiresponsive behavior of the framework is certified by the exceptional quenching of fluorescence by Fe3+ ions over other potentially interfering metal ions. The detection of Fe3+ ions involve a visible colorimetric change in the solid and solution phase upon Fe3+ ion encapsulation, which is important for practical applications. Comprehensive studies indicated that concurrent presence of dynamic and static quenchings as well as RET are responsible for such efficient sensing in 1', and the results are in harmony with the predictions from theoretical calculations. Besides, AND as well as OR molecular logic gates are constructed based on the discriminative luminescent recognition of each analyte. To our knowledge, the dual-functionalized CSMCRI-1 represents an exclusive example of a tetrasensoric framework with good recyclability that opens up a platform to fabricate smart luminescent MOFs with multimode logic operations for potential detection of diverse harmful pollutants using a single fluorescent material.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg; 0.1 mmol), azobenzene-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2 azdc) (27.2 mg; 0.1 mmol), and meso-α,β-di­(4-pyridyl)­glycol (bpg) (21.6 mg; 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of DMF that was placed in a 15 mL tightly capped Teflon-lined glass vial and heated under autogenous pressure at 90 °C for 48 h. Block-shaped orange crystals were isolated in 60% yield. The crystals were washed with DMF and finally dried in air. The guest solvents in the as-synthesized crystals were exchanged with dichloromethane and degassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate a solvent-free framework [Zn3(bpg)1.5(azdc)3] (1′). Anal. Calcd for C60H42N9O15Zn3 (1′): C, 54.38; H, 3.19; N, 9.51%. Found: C, 54.50; H, 3.23; N, 9.45%.

Synthesis of [Zn3(bpg)1.5(azdc)3]⋅(DMF)5.9⋅(H2O)1.05 (CSMCRI-1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (30 mg; 0.1 mmol), azobenzene-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2 azdc) (27.2 mg; 0.1 mmol), and meso-α,β-di(4-pyridyl)glycol (bpg) (21.6 mg; 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of DMF that was placed in a 15 mL tightly capped Teflon-lined glass vial and heated under autogenous pressure at 90 °C for 48 h. Block-shaped orange crystals were isolated in 60% yield. The crystals were washed with DMF and finally dried in air. The guest solvents in the as-synthesized crystals were exchanged with dichloromethane and degassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate a solvent-free framework [Zn3(bpg)1.5(azdc)3] (1'). Anal. Calcd for C60H42N9O15Zn3 (1'): C, 54.38; H, 3.19; N, 9.51%. Found: C, 54.50; H, 3.23; N, 9.45%.

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of CSMCRI-1 under N2 atmosphere shows a two-step weight loss (calcd 25.32 wt %) that corresponds to the release of water and DMF guest molecules (Figure S3a). The desolvated CSMCRI-1 (hereafter 1′) does not reveal any plateau up to 370 °C and decomposes thereafter. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-synthesized crystals reveals complete agreement with that of the simulated pattern, indicating high crystallinity and phase purity of the sample (a). Desolvation leads to a slight shift of Bragg’s reflections (a) that may result because of the release of solvent guests from the porous channel. Interestingly, the low-angle peaks were restored upon exposure of 1′ to DMF (a). It is worth mentioning that such a modification in the PXRD patterns upon desolvation and resolvation is not unique and has been realized in the interpenetrated pillar-layer frameworks. In addition, stability of CSMCRI-1 was checked in diverse organic solvents as well as in water and open air. As displayed in b, the characteristic peaks in PXRD remain unchanged in all cases up to 24 h, whereas slight broadening of peaks occurs upon exposure to water for a prolonged time. Variable temperature PXRD up to 250 °C reveals sufficient stability of the framework (Figure S4). To assess the permanent porosity, nitrogen gas sorption isotherm was attempted. Prior to measurement, the guest solvents in the as-synthesized crystals were exchanged with dichloromethane and degassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate 1′. The framework shows 86 cm3/g of N2 gas uptake at 77 K up to 1.0 relative pressure (P/P 0) that corresponds to a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 112.69 m2/g. The result corroborates the presence of porosity (Figure S3b) and further indicates that the −OH groups of the linker do not appreciably reduce the accessible space in 1′.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Establishment of Stability and Permanent Porosity

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of CSMCRI-1 under N2 atmosphere shows a two-step weight loss (calcd 25.32 wt %) that corresponds to the release of water and DMF guest molecules (Figure S3a). The desolvated CSMCRI-1 (hereafter 1') does not reveal any plateau up to 370 °C and decomposes thereafter. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-synthesized crystals reveals complete agreement with that of the simulated pattern, indicating high crystallinity and phase purity of the sample (a). Desolvation leads to a slight shift of Bragg's reflections (a) that may result because of the release of solvent guests from the porous channel. Interestingly, the low-angle peaks were restored upon exposure of 1' to DMF (a). It is worth mentioning that such a modification in the PXRD patterns upon desolvation and resolvation is not unique and has been realized in the interpenetrated pillar-layer frameworks. In addition, stability of CSMCRI-1 was checked in diverse organic solvents as well as in water and open air. As displayed in b, the characteristic peaks in PXRD remain unchanged in all cases up to 24 h, whereas slight broadening of peaks occurs upon exposure to water for a prolonged time. Variable temperature PXRD up to 250 °C reveals sufficient stability of the framework (Figure S4). To assess the permanent porosity, nitrogen gas sorption isotherm was attempted. Prior to measurement, the guest solvents in the as-synthesized crystals were exchanged with dichloromethane and degassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate 1'. The framework shows 86 cm3/g of N2 gas uptake at 77 K up to 1.0 relative pressure (P/P 0) that corresponds to a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 112.69 m2/g. The result corroborates the presence of porosity (Figure S3b) and further indicates that the -OH groups of the linker do not appreciably reduce the accessible space in 1'.
